journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Effect of synthesis method on magnetic and thermal properties of polyvinylidene fluoride/Fe3O4 nanocomposites

article-meta.aff: Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Masoud Frounchi, Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran. Email: frounchi@sharif.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Polyvinylidene fluoride magnetic nanocomposite films were prepared by solution casting using two types of magnetic nanoparticles: (a) magnetic nanoparticles synthesized by co-precipitation method using oleic acid as a coating agent and (b) Fe3O4 nanoparticles prepared by hydrolysis method without using a coating agent. Dynamic light scattering measurements showed mean diameters of 135 and 46 nm in co-precipitation and hydrolysis methods, respectively. Scanning electron microscopy showed that the magnetic nanoparticles were uniformly dispersed inside the polymer matrix. X-ray diffraction confirmed that Fe3O4 nanoparticles induced nucleation of β- crystalline phase in the matrix polymer. The thermal properties of polyvinylidene fluoride magnetic nanocomposites were evaluated by differential scanning calorimetry. The decrease in crystallinity of the nanocomposites was concomitant with the increase in the melting temperature. The magnetic properties of the nanocomposites were investigated by vibrating sample magnetometer. The magnetic properties increased with increasing Fe3O4 content and the polyvinylidene fluoride magnetic nanocomposites prepared by hydrolysis method showed higher magnetization.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is a great interest in materials having magnetic properties for various potential applications such as magnetic sensors, electromagnetic shielding, microwave-absorbing materials and medical applications.1–6 Among the various magnetic nanostructure materials, ferrite (Fe3O4) nanoparticles have attracted much attention because of their unique properties. It has been reported that the magnetic behavior of Fe3O4 nanoparticles changes with the particles size. Therefore, the synthesis and processing of these nanoparticles has become an interesting topic. A variety of methods have been developed to synthesize Fe3O4 nanoparticles, including co-precipitation, thermal decomposition and/or reduction and hydrothermal synthesis.7–10

Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) is a crystalline polymer and can develop various crystalline phases such as α, β and γ.The β -phase has piezoelectric properties, so many attempts have been made to increase β-phase content in the crystalline structure of PVDF. It has been shown that addition of nanoparticles such as nanoclays11 and nanoferrites could enhance β-phase content.12,13 In one study,12 the inclusion of iron oxide nanoparticles in PVDF nucleated β-crystalline phase and both magnetization and dielectric constant increased with increasing iron oxide content. In another study,13 the addition of NiFe2O4 and CoFe2O4 ferrite nanoparticles in PVDF matrix boosted the nucleation of the β-phase. The essential factor for the nucleation of the β-phase in the ferrites/PVDF nanocomposites was attributed to presence of the static electric interaction between the magnetic particles with a negative zeta potential and the CH2 groups of PVDF having a positive charge density. These nanocomposites with both magnetic and piezoelectric properties promise great potential for use as sensors and actuators.14,15

So far no detailed investigation on the effect of preparation method on the properties of such magnetic polymeric nanocomposites has been reported. In this article, we report the synthesis of PVDF/Fe3O4 magnetic nanocomposites by solution casting method. Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles were synthesized by two methods: (a) co-precipitation method using oleic acid as a coating agent and (b) Fe3O4 nanoparticles prepared by hydrolysis method without using a coating agent.

sec.title: Experimental
sec.p: PVDF granules were Hylar 460 from Solvay, Belgium. Ferrous chloride (FeCl2.4H2O), ferric chloride (FeCl3.6H2O), ammonium hydroxide (NH3.H2O), oleic acid, potassium hydroxide, potassium chloride and dimethyl formamide (DMF) were purchased from Merck.

sec.title: Co-precipitation method using oleic acid as a coating agent
sec.p: First, FeCl2.4H2O and FeCl3.6H2O with 1:2 molar ratios were dissolved in distilled water. The solution was stirred and then aqueous ammonium hydroxide (25–28% wt/wt) was added to the solution. The color changed from yellow to black, indicating formation of magnetite nanoparticles. Then, under vigorous stirring, 1 ml oleic acid was slowly dropped into the dispersion at 70℃ over 1 h. The process was carried out under nitrogen to prevent oxidation.

sec.title: Hydrolysis method without coating agent
sec.p: Mixed powders of FeCl2.4H2O, FeCl3.6H2O and KCl were dissolved into deionized water and stirred at room temperature for 30 min under N2 flow to ensure an inert atmosphere. Then KOH powder was added to the solution and the color was changed to black. After vigorous stirring for 2 h, the product was washed with distilled water and put in an ultrasonic bath for 15 min. This method was called as hydrolysis method.

sec.title: Preparation of PVDF/Fe3O4 nanocomposite films
sec.p: PVDF and nanocomposite films were made using solution casting method. Appropriate amount of Fe3O4 nanoparticles prepared by co-precipitation and hydrolysis methods were dispersed in DMF using ultrasonic bath for 2 h to ensure the dispersion of Fe3O4 aggregation throughout the solvent. PVDF flakes (1:10 PVDF:DMF) were continuously mixed with a magnetic stirrer at 75℃ until the PVDF was dissolved thoroughly in the solvent. Then the DMF–Fe3O4 solution was added into PVDF solution and stirred for 1 day. Solution casting was done by pouring the solution on a glass substrate. Once the solvent had evaporated and crystallization of PVDF was completed, the film was placed in a vacuum oven at approximately 100℃ to assist the removal of any residual solvent in the films.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: The mean hydrodynamic diameter and size distribution of Fe3O4 nanoparticles were measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS) at room temperature using a Zetasizer, Nano series Malvern instrument. The nanoparticles were suspended in deionized water at a concentration of 1 mg/l. The morphology and structure of the magnetic Fe3O4/PVDF nanocomposites were determined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Crystal structure of the nanocomposites was characterized by X-Ray diffraction (XRD) pattern recorded by Xpert MPD diffractometer with Cu kα radiation (1.5406 Å) generated at 40 kv and 30 mA. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) of magnetic nanocomposites was studied by a Pyris1 Perkin Elmer instrument, at the heating rate of 10℃/min under a constant nitrogen flow (100 ml/min). The magnetic properties of Fe3O4 nanoparticles and Fe3O4/PVDF nanocomposites were measured at room temperature using a MDK6 vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Figure 1(a) and (b) show the size distribution of Fe3O4 nanoparticles in deionized water measured by DLS method. The mean hydrodynamic diameters were about 135 and 46 nm in co-precipitation and hydrolysis methods, respectively. As shown, the distributions are quite narrow, indicating almost uniform particle sizes. The fact that the particles are engulfed by water molecules makes the apparent diameter look larger than it is. It seems that the oleic acid-treated particles absorb more water and appear larger. Figure 1.
Size distribution of Fe3O4 nanoparticles prepared by: (a) co-precipitation and (b) hydrolysis methods measured by DLS technique.
DLS: dynamic light scattering.

Figure 2(a) and (b) show the SEM micrograph of the synthesized iron oxide particles. The SEM images of Figure 2(c) and (d) show the presence of spherical Fe3O4 particles in PVDF matrix. Fe3O4 nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed throughout the nanocomposites. The nanoparticles of Fe3O4 exhibit agglomeration in the polymer matrix, with sizes ranging from 500 nm up to 1 µm. The nanocomposite films containing 10 wt% Fe3O4 exhibit smaller agglomerations. However, the aggregation of particles becomes more prominent in the films containing 30 wt% Fe3O4. The Fe3O4 nanoparticles prepared by hydrolysis method were smaller and looked more uniform in size compared with those prepared by co-precipitation. Figure 2.
SEM images of: (a) magnetite nanoparticles prepared by co-precipitation, (b) magnetite nanoparticles prepared by hydrolysis, (c) Fe3O4/PVDF nanocomposite with 10 wt% Fe3O4 prepared by co-precipitation, (d) Fe3O4/PVDF nanocomposite with 10 wt% Fe3O4 prepared by hydrolysis, (e) Fe3O4/PVDF nanocomposite with 30 wt% Fe3O4 prepared by co-precipitation and (f) Fe3O4/PVDF nanocomposite with 30 wt% Fe3O4 prepared by hydrolysis.
SEM: scanning electron microscope; PVDF: polyvinylidene fluoride.

Figure 3 shows XRD patterns of Fe3O4 nanoparticles and the nanocomposite with 10 wt% Fe3O4. The characteristic diffraction peaks of the magnetite nanoparticle are located at 2θ = 31°, 35°, 43°, 50°, 57° and 62°. These angles correspond to (220) (311) (400) (204) (511) (440) planes.9 The average size of the Fe3O4 crystal particles can be calculated by the following Scherrer equation16 d=0.89λBcosθ where d is the crystal grain size, λ is the X-ray wavelength and B is the full width at half maximum of the XRD peak at θ = 35° corresponding to the plane (311). The calculated crystal grain size was about 5.5 nm. Figure 3.
XRD patterns of: (a) Fe3O4 nanoparticles prepared by co-precipitation, (b) Fe3O4 nanoparticles prepared by hydrolysis, (c) magnetic nanocomposite with 10 wt% of Fe3O4 prepared by co-precipitation and (d) magnetic nanocomposite with 10 wt% of Fe3O4 prepared by hydrolysis.
XRD: X-ray diffraction.

The diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 appeared in the XRD patterns of the nanocomposites at lower intensities commensurate with Fe3O4 concentration. The XRD patterns of pristine PVDF in Figure 4 shows five characteristic peaks corresponding to (100), (020), (110), (021) and (002) crystal planes for the α-phase.11 Upon addition of Fe3O4 nanoparticles into PVDF, there appears a sharp peak corresponding to the crystal plane of (110)/(200) (Figure 3(c) and (d)), indicating α to β crystalline-phase transformation. The latter transformation has also been reported in PVDF/nanoclay nanocomposites11 and PVDF/iron oxide.12 Thus, it was inferred that the nanoparticles promoted the crystallization of the PVDF toward β-phase formation. Figure 4.
X-ray diffraction pattern of pristine PVDF.
XRD: X-ray diffraction; PVDF: polyvinylidene fluoride.

The thermal behavior and crystallinity of the nanocomposite films were examined by DSC. Figure 5 shows the second heating thermogram of PVDF and PVDF/Fe3O4 nanocomposites. The first run was performed to remove the thermal history of the PVDF. The melting temperature, enthalpy of melting (ΔHm) and crystallinity of the nanocomposites are listed in the Table 1. The enthalpy of melting ΔHm and crystallinity are correlated according to the following equation crystallinity=ΔHmΔH0×100 % where ΔH0 is the melting enthalpy of 100% crystalline PVDF, which is 102.5 J/g.11 The nanoparticles mass was subtracted from the sample mass in crystallinity calculations. Figure 5.
DSC thermograms of PVDF and the nanocomposites.
DSC: differential scanning calorimetry; PVDF: polyvinylidene fluoride.
Table 1.
DSC data of PVDF magnetic nanocomposite films.
Tm (℃) ΔHm (J/g) Crystallinity (%)
PVDF 157 21.22 35
Nanocomposite 10% Fe3O4 co-precipitation 159 18.75 34.2
Nanocomposite 10% Fe3O4 hydrolysis 160 15.94 29.2
Nanocomposite 30% Fe3O4 co-precipitation 159 12.95 30.5
Nanocomposite 30% Fe3O4 hydrolysis 160 13.34 31.5
DSC: differential scanning calorimetry; PVDF: polyvinylidene fluoride.

As shown in Table 1, there is an increase of a few degrees in the melting temperature of PVDF after incorporation of Fe3O4 nanoparticles in the nanocomposites. This result has also been reported recently by other researchers.12 The increase in the melting temperature of PVDF is along with a decreased level of crystallinity in the nanocomposites. However, given the presence of a large amount of nanoparticles in the nanocomposites (10% and 30%), the variation in the crystallinity is limited only to a few percent. The decrease in crystallinity could be attributed to the fact that the addition of Fe3O4 nanoparticles imposes restrictions on the movement of PVDF chain segments hindering them from acquiring the alignment for crystallization.

The magnetic hysteresis loops are shown in Figure 6 and the saturation magnetization (Ms) and coercivity (Hc) are given in Table 2. Figure 6.
VSM curve of PVDF magnetic nanocomposite: (a) co-precipitation (b) hydrolysis.
VSM: vibrating sample magnetometer; PVDF: polyvinylidene fluoride.
Table 2.
Magnetization values of nanoparticles and nanocomposites.
Ms (emu/g) Hc(Oe)
Fe3O4 co-precipitation 25.6 1.75
Fe3O4 hydrolysis 28.5 6.45
Nanocomposite 10% Fe3O4 co-precipitation 1.35 1.5
Nanocomposite 10% Fe3O4 hydrolysis 2.81 4.5
Nanocomposite 30% Fe3O4 co-precipitation 5.55 1.25
Nanocomposite 30% Fe3O4 hydrolysis 6.02 3.11

The values of saturation magnetization of nanoparticles synthesized using co-precipitation and hydrolysis methods were 25.6 and 28.5 emu/g, respectively. The lower saturation magnetization value of Fe3O4 synthesized by co-precipitation could be attributed to the larger particle size. The saturation magnetization values of the nanocomposites were lower but showed increasing trend with increase in Fe3O4 content.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Fe3O4 nanoparticles synthesized by two different methods, co-precipitation and hydrolysis, were used to prepare the PVDF–magnetite nanocomposite films by solution casting method. The nanoparticles incorporated in the PVDF matrix showed some agglomeration. While the Fe3O4 nanoparticles prepared by hydrolysis method had a size distribution of 30–80 nm, Fe3O4 synthesized by co-precipitation had larger particle size and varied from 100 to 200 nm. The Fe3O4 nanoparticles decreased somewhat the crystallinity of PVDF along with some increase in the melting temperature of the PVDF. The saturation magnetization (Ms) of the PVDF/Fe3O4 nanocomposites showed an increasing trend with the increase of Fe3O4 content for both Fe3O4 synthesis methods. The nanocomposites were prepared by Fe3O4 from hydrolysis method had higher magnetization values.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
